poem:
**Abundance in the Cart**

In aisles of plenty, the shelves  
sway with promises—beans,  
bottles, electric whims,  
each labeled efficiency.  
Olive oil rivers,  
toothbrush armies,  
all dissolve in the cupboard dust,  
in forgotten corners.  
A clawing want—  
unwound by accumulation,  
defeated by our own hands,  
barely grasping the worth  
of single bounty.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "I gave up bulk buying – and changed my attitude to money | Emma Brockes One of the conventional pleasures of the American shopping experience has been buying more than you need while telling yourself you are being highly efficient. Beans in 12-packs; two, gallon-bottles of olive oil shackled at the collar bone; high-end electronics like the multipack Philips Sonicare electric toothbrushes I once bought for $300. $300! Where are those toothbrushes now? No idea.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: I gave up bulk buying – and changed my attitude to money | Emma Brockes One of the conventional pleasures of the American shopping experience has been buying more than you need while telling yourself you are being highly efficient. Beans in 12-packs; two, gallon-bottles of olive oil shackled at the collar bone; high-end electronics like the multipack Philips Sonicare electric toothbrushes I once bought for $300. $300! Where are those toothbrushes now? No idea.
